Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Novel Rare Earth Metal Oxysulfate (RE2O2SO4) for Upconversion
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is co-funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) and the Ceramics Program (CER).

Non-technical Description: This project focuses on an inorganic material system, oxysulfate (RE2O2SO4) doped with metal elements, in the form of nanometer spheres and explores its potential for converting low-frequency light to higher-frequency light (upconversion). Upconversion is used in various photonic applications including biological imaging. The project offers students the opportunity to acquire skills in nanoparticle synthesis, functionalization, structural characterizations, and optical property measurements. The research activities of this project are integrated with an educational mission in terms of course development and special seminars. As a Hispanic-Serving Institution, New Mexico State University offers significant opportunities for outreach and educational activities that involve K-12 students and underrepresented minorities including those at the NMSU community colleges.

Technical Description: Bulk glass and crystalline materials are usually used for upconversion, but bulk materials are often not suitable for certain applications such as biological imaging. Upconversion materials on nanometer scales are desirable. However, synthesis of small nanocrystals that exhibit high monodispersibility and excellent upconversion properties remains a challenge. The goal of this project is to establish a scientific basis for the design of small monodisperse rare-earth-metal-doped oxysulfate nanospheres for upconversion. The research team aims to develope an effective synthesis route, biomolecule-assisted hydrothermal method, to control the size and shape of nanospheres, as well as to tune the upconversion properties to enable their practical applications. The research activities are designed to develop a fundamental understanding of the formation mechanism of the nanospheres with controlled size and shape; to investigate the energy transfer mechanism between the sensitizer and the activator; and to reveal the relationship between the composition, particle size and shape, crystal structure, and luminescent properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rare-earth based compounds have been extensively used as phosphors for a variety of applications due to their unique luminescent properties, which are directly attributed from the abundant 4f electronic transitions between different energy levels. By simply changing the combination of sensitizer and activator, these phosphors can either convert the high energy ultraviolet light into visible light through the photo downconversion process, or transfer the near infrared long-wavelength excitation radiation into shorter visible wavelengths by photon upconversion. The upconversion materials show significant application potential, but the actual research and utilization of upconversion has been mainly achieved on bulk materials for the past decades, which are not able to be directly applied in biological sciences. These barriers can be primarily ascribed to the difficulties in the synthesis of small nanocrystals with both high dispersibility and excellent upconversion properties in aqueous solutions. Upconversion emission from RE3+-doped nanocrystals offers a great opportunity for the optical imaging or labeling in biological science without limitations come from the organic fluorophores, such as broad emission bandwidths, small anti-Stokes and Stokes shifts, low photochemical stability, toxicity. These shortcomings can be compensated by rare-earth ion based upconversion materials, which also provide the merits of significantly minimized background autofluorescence, photobleaching, and photodamage to biological specimens, which make plenty of space for in vivo observation with substantially high spatial resolution and offer large sample penetration depths. These are the reasons that rare-earth-based upconversion materials have been increasingly applied as a novel type of luminescent optical labels in biological assays and medical imaging and have become promising alternatives to organic fluorophores. In this project, we engineered uniform rare-earth-doped RE2O2SO4 hollow spheres with readily controllable size and morphology by changing surfactants and temperature, and its fundametal application as upconversion materials, through which the energy transfer and migration in this material system were elucidated.

Second, to provide a workforce trained in the experimental work, the project placed much emphasis on training students of various levels in solution preparation, materials characterization, and optical properties. The PI developed Nanoscience and Nanotechnology for the NMSU Chemical & Materials Engineering department, also for the Physics Department. The project supports three-week lab work for the students who enroll in the Nanoscience class for the nanomaterials synthesis and microscope imaging; The project also supports several graduate students, undergraduate students, and one high school girl to attend the MRS Spring meeting 2015 in Phoenix. One graduate student graduated with Ph.D and now he is a postdoc at UCLA. The high school girl is now at NMSU for her undergraduate study. Oral presentations were delivered by graduate and undergraduate students in the MRS, ECS, ACS, AIChE meetings; and 5 journal papers were published. The project promotes collaboration between mid-career faculty at NMSU and new faculty at NMT.
